awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Social modulation of migratory timing and endocrine mechanisms of migration in two flexible migrants
awd_abstract_narration:
Animal migration is a centrally important life cycle stage for thousands of species, it is critical to the dynamics of many ecosystems, has impacts on human health, and is a process that is particularly prone to disturbance. Thus, research on the control of migration is critical from both basic and applied perspectives. Understanding how animals decide when to move is of particular importance given that this can dictate whether or not they arrive at their destination at an appropriate time for reproduction or overwintering. Many animals move in groups and social interactions and social cues are expected to be important in the decisions that animals make in preparation for and during migration. Yet, there is little known about the role of social cues in determining when animals begin or end migration or about the physiological mechanisms by which social signals might act to influence migratory timing. This collaborative project will address these two knowledge gaps using two species of migratory songbirds that have flexible migratory schedules and that are highly sensitive to social information. Results of this work will advance our understanding of how social cues influence both migratory timing and the hormonal regulation of migration. This project will also provide training and mentoring for undergraduate and graduate students. Outreach activities linked to the project will engage elementary school students and the general public in migratory biology. Training and outreach activities at the university level and in elementary schools will target individuals from groups that are traditionally underrepresented in STEM fields.

The first goal of this collaborative project is to evaluate the influence of social cues (specifically, the migratory state of conspecifics) on the timing of migration. Experiments will be carried out to test the hypotheses that birds use cues from conspecifics to fine-tune timing of initiation and termination of migration. Social cues have not been well studied in the context of migratory timing and the project's inclusion of the termination phase of migration will be important in advancing the understanding of this particularly understudied phase of migration. The second goal of the project is to advance understanding of the endocrine and neuroendocrine regulation of migratory transitions, with the further objective of investigating how social cues influence endocrine and neuroendocrine parameters to potentially alter migratory timing. Thus, investigators will quantify changes in circulating steroid hormones and the availability of their receptors in the brain and peripheral tissues across transitions into and out of a migratory state. This type of whole-body approach to understanding endocrine mechanisms in the context of migration is unique. The investigators will also experimentally manipulate social cues to evaluate endocrine and neuroendocrine mechanisms by which these cues might influence migratory timing. The results of this project will thus greatly broaden understanding of the roles of social cues and plasticity of endocrine mechanisms in life history transitions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Animal migration is a centrally important life cycle stage for thousands of species, is critical to the dynamics of many ecosystems, has impacts on human health, and is a process that is particularly prone to disturbance by global environmental change. Thus, understanding the mechanisms that regulate animal migrations is critical from both basic and applied perspectives. This project has generated important insights into the regulation of both the initiation of migration, and the heretofore poorly understood process by which it is terminated. Focusing primarily on two different species of birds (red crossbills and pine siskins), our research has revealed the importance of social cues (i.e., information from other individuals of the same and other species) to migratory decisions, the extent to which social cues of varying degrees of specificity are used, and sex differences in the use of social cues. More broadly, this research has advanced our understanding of the process by which environmental cues are integrated to timing annual cycle events, including migration. 

The bird species that have been the main focus of this project exhibit highly flexible migratory behavior, often termed facultative migration. Consequently, research on this project has shed new light on facultative migrations, which are diverse in nature and are an important mechanism by which animals cope with rapid or unpredictable environmental change. Facultative migrations are common in animals and can vary from being exploitative in nature, where animals move to exploit plentiful resources, to those that are evasive in nature, where animals move to avoid declining resources or in response to declining body condition. For instance, evasive migrations can often occur in response to poor access to food. We found that under such circumstances, social information from neighboring birds can induce physiological changes that allow birds to better prepare for food shortage. Moreover, we have found evidence for this effect in multiple finch species (red crossbills, pine siskins, house finches) with widely variable migratory habits, suggesting this may be a widespread phenomenon.

This project has also substantially advanced our understanding of the role of steroid hormones in regulating the behavioral and physiological changes associated with migratory transitions. Findings from the project have challenged the frequent assumption that corticosterone is key in stimulating migration generally and facultative migration specifically. Our results suggest any role of corticosterone is likely relatively narrow and context specific. However, our results indicate that one means by which social cues may influence behavior and physiology in the context of evasive migrations is through effects on corticosterone signaling. Our results also reveal that testosterone acting through androgen receptors plays a role in stimulating at least some forms of facultative migration. 

This project provided training and mentoring to undergraduate students (9 at WSU, 5 at EMU, and 14 at OSU), post baccalaureate students (1 at WSU, 3 at OSU), graduate students (4 at WSU, 2 at EMU and 6 at OSU), and a postdoctoral scholar (1 at WSU). Many of these trainees on the project belong to groups underrepresented in STEM. Project trainees gained experience in a range of skills including experimental design, animal care and husbandry, behavioral data collection techniques, physiological data collection techniques, data analysis, theoretical modeling, as well as oral and written communication. Mentoring for career development as appropriate for career stage and individual goals was also provided. Public outreach activities included public talks and events, including in local rural and urban communities. Outreach and educational activities for K-12 students associated with the project included the creation and delivery of a 5-week, active-learning summer program about birds to over 100 third and fourth grade students in a low-income community of Flint, MI. Materials developed for K-12 bird camps have been made available to collaborators. This project also supported the production of a new permanent exhibit on migratory biology for the Charles R. Conner Museum of Natural History at Washington State University in Pullman, WA, which receives ~14,000-39,000 visitors each year, including many K-12 school groups.
